user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_resume_connection:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_resume_connection (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Cannot resume connections without enabling " \
                  "MHD_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME!\n"));
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  connection->resuming = true;
  daemon->resuming = true;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  if ( (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
       (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "r")) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to signal resume via inter-thread " \
                 "communication channel.\n"));
#endif
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no explicit compiler language extensions in the provided fragment. The code uses only standard C constructs and portable preprocessor conditionals: - Conditional compilation (#if defined(...)) is standard. - The backslash used to continue long string literals is the standard source-line splicing mechanism (not an extension). - Use of true/false is the standard C99 boolean macros if <stdbool.h> is used; nothing in the snippet shows a compiler-specific boolean. - The identifiers and macros (e.g. _MHD_EXTERN, MHD_PANIC, MHD_mutex_lock_chk_) are ordinary macros; although they could expand to compiler-specific attributes (for example __attribute__ or __declspec) that would be extensions, no such tokens (e.g., __attribute__, __declspec, __asm, typeof, __builtin_*, ({ ... }), nested functions, or other documented compiler extensions) appear directly in this source fragment. - No inline assembly, statement-expressions, typeof, zero-length arrays, or other known language extensions are present. Because the rule requires reporting only explicit uses of compiler language extensions as stated in compiler documentation, and none are present in this code snippet, there are no suspicious fragments to report.
